name: Funicolare città alta
description: Bergamo offers a direct connection between the lower and upper parts of the city thanks to a funicular. The line is approximately 240 metres long and has a difference in height of 85 metres. The first funicular, with a traditional two-car system, was built in 1887 to a design by the Emilian engineer Alessandro Ferretti.

name: Piazza vecchia
description: Piazza Vecchia is the symbol of Città Alta: for centuries it was the fulcrum of Bergamo's political power and still today continues to be the place where people meet and enjoy their leisure time. The Piazza is overlooked by majestic and imposing buildings arranged according to a harmonious and perfect geometry.

name: S.Maria Maggiore
description: The basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore is a church located in Bergamo Alta, in Piazza del Duomo. Built in the second half of the XII century, the exterior retains the original Romanesque-Lombard architectural lines, while the interior is decorated in Baroque style.

name: Campanone
description: In the heart of Piazza Vecchia stands Torre Civica, known as Campanone, which at 52.76 metres high offers a breathtaking panoramic view of the old town. At the top, which can be reached on foot (230 steps) or more conveniently by lift, is the largest bell in Lombardia. Every day at 10 pm, Campanone strikes its striking hundred chimes.

name: Palazzo terzi
description: Palazzo Terzi was built in the XVII century. It is located on the edge of the fortress in the upper part of Bergamo, and is the most important Baroque palace in the city. Numerous guided tours allow visitors to immerse themselves in the Baroque era, thanks to dozens of rooms that preserve period furniture and furnishings.

name: Mura Veneziane
description: The Venetian walls of Bergamo are an imposing architectural construction dating back to the XVI century.  On the outside, the ramparts give the city the appearance of an impregnable fortress. Since, 9 July 2017, the Venetian walls have been a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Porta S.Giacomo
description: Porta San Giacomo is among the most beautiful of the gateways from the Venetian walls to Bergamo Alta. Built in 1592, it is the only one in pinkish white marble, which makes it stand out against the grey stone of the defensive walls.

name: Cattedrale S.Alessandro
description: The Cathedral of Sant'Alessandro is the main Catholic place of worship in Bergamo, mother church of the diocese with the same name. It is dedicated to San Alessandro, patron saint of Bergamo, and is located in Bergamo Alta, in Piazza del Duomo, next to Palazzo della Ragione and the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore.

name: Antico lavatoio
description: A long white marble basin, divided into several parts, with an elegant cast-iron and sheet metal roof. The Lavatoio in Via Lupo in Bergamo Alta, built in 1891, is still a model in terms of design. This Lavatoio worked until the 1950s and today is carefully preserved as a precious reminder of the past.

name: Ex Chiesa S.Rocco
description: The Church of San Rocco is a Catholic place of worship, located in the upper part of the city of Bergamo. It was built during the plague epidemic in the XVI century and was dedicated to the Virgin Mary. However, the church was suppressed for worship and is owned by the city's municipal administration.

name: Via Solata
description: Via Solata, located in Bergamo Alta, is a beautiful and out-of-this-world street, in every sense, since phones have no signal. One can take pleasant walks in the evening thanks to the ban on cars. There are also numerous places to taste typical products.

name: Convento di S.Francesco - Museo
description: Built between the end of the XIII and the beginning of the XVI century, the Convent of San Francesco is a fine example of medieval convent architecture, built around cloisters. Adorning and embellishing the entire complex are numerous frescoes dating back to the XIV century, some of which are still visible today.

name: Porta S.Agostino
description: Porta Sant'Agostino, named after the large complex of the monastery of Sant’Agostino, is the gate facing east; it was built at the same time as the walls (XVI century). Since 9th July 2017, together with the Venetian walls and the other main gates, it has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Piazzale S.Agostino
description: The Piazza of Sant’Agostino owes its name to the church dedicated to the saint of the same name, which overlooks the square. Historical sources report that this church was already present in the area during the XIV century and was later deconsecrated in 1797 with the Napoleonic invasion. Since 2015, it has been the lecture hall of the University of Bergamo.

name: Parco della Fara
description: If you are looking for a place to relax before continuing your visit to the upper part of the City, here you are in the right place. Fara is a large meadow where you can have a picnic, play football, or even just lie on the grass admiring the splendid panorama of Bergamo's valleys before entering the old town.

name: Baluardo della Fara
description: The Fara bastion is one of the fourteen bastions along the walls. It provides continuous views of the lower city, the plain and the extraordinary richness of Bergamo Alta, which, seen from below, contributes with its monuments to the discovery of the city from a truly privileged position.

name: Porta S.Lorenzo
description: Porta San Lorenzo, located to the north, is the smallest of the gates to the upper part of the city of Bergamo. It was the gateway into the city for those arriving from the valleys to the north of Bergamo and from beyond the Alps.

name: Fontana del Vàgine
description: Fountain of Vàgine is the oldest fountain in Bergamo. Some legends are connected with it: During the Roman Empire, male infants were immersed in it for some seconds. If they did not cry ('vagito' in italian, hence the name) they would be considered weak and therefore unfit for military life. Another legend is that the water from it was good luck for young brides who wished to have children.

name: Piazza della Cittadella
description: Piazza Cittadella is a symbolic and historical place in the city starting from the XIV century. During that epoch, the entrances were closed to public transit, so if you wanted to reach the city centre you had to pass through the two gates, so that the soldiers could control everything that entered and left the city.

name: Museo di Scienze Naturali
description: The Enrico Caffi Museum of Natural Sciences in Bergamo, located in Città Alta, holds collections referring to all naturalistic disciplines (more than one million of artifacts), and has an exhibition area about 1,800 m². The museum was founded in 1871, and officially opened in 1918. Interactivity and innovation are the pillars of the museum.
